<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?><rss xmlns:a10="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" version="2.0"><channel><title>Style Sheet</title><link>http://www.hgtv.ca/blog/</link><description /><lastBuildDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 16:04:00 -0400</lastBuildDate><a10:id /><item><guid isPermaLink="false">62224</guid><link>http://www.hgtv.ca/blog/sam-pynn-on-when-to-stop-painting-a-slanted-ceiling/</link><title>Sam Pynn on When to Stop Painting a Slanted Ceiling</title><description><p><br></p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnonwhentostoppaintingaslantedceili_e313-sampynn-6_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="626" title="SamPynn-6" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="SamPynn-6" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnonwhentostoppaintingaslantedceili_e313-sampynn-6_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a>
</p><p><br></p><p>Flashback to when Sam Pynn settled a cohabitation dispute involving a slanted popcorn ceiling, that went a little something like this...</p><p><b><br></b></p><p><b>From Marilyn:</b> <i></i></p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnonwhentostoppaintingaslantedceili_e313-sampopcornceiling1_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="465" title="SamPopcornCeiling1" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="SamPopcornCeiling1" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnonwhentostoppaintingaslantedceili_e313-sampopcornceiling1_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a></p><p><i>This is a bedroom that is going to be painted soon and there is a disagreement about the slanted portion as to whether it should be painted as part of the wall or as part of the ceiling. The previous owners painted it white as if it were the ceiling (it is also stucco the same as the ceiling!) but I was thinking, stucco or not, it would look better painted the wall colour.&nbsp; Painting the whole room one colour is not an option here -- the man of the house wants white ceilings!&nbsp; HELP! (soon please if you can :-) ) <br>Marilyn</i><p><br></p><p><b>Sam Pynn suggests:&nbsp; </b>Dear Marilyn, <br>In addition to highlighting weird angles, men also like giant brown leather sofas, recessed lighting plans that resemble an airport runway, and knotty pine trim (the kind you’d find in a sauna), but that doesn’t make it right (okay, okay, I’ve seen knotty pine work well in a country house). <br>Here's the thing, just because someone else made the mistake of stuccoing those angles doesn’t mean that you have to live with them highlighted in white. However, before you pull out your paint roller or spray-paint gun, have a professional take a look to see if the “popcorn” can be removed. Once your bedroom is covered with plastic sheets to protect the floors, walls, and electrical outlets, the stucco should be soaked with water which will allow it to scrape off like butter using a wide putty knife. I’m recommending a professional because sometimes popcorn from the '70s contains asbestos.&nbsp; <p>Whether you decide to remove the stucco&nbsp; (may be from the ceiling too?) or not, paint the angles the same colour as the wall and the ceiling a soft white. You’ll feel better about the room once those sharp angles have been softened with a little paint -- promise! <p>All the best, <br>Sam Pynn <p><br></p><p><br></p><p>You know what else is cool? We ran a poll to see what our fans though Marilyn should do, and here are the results! </p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnonwhentostoppaintingaslantedceili_e313-sampopcornceiling_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="371" title="SamPopcornCeiling" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="SamPopcornCeiling" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnonwhentostoppaintingaslantedceili_e313-sampopcornceiling_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a>
</p><p><br></p><p>Please note: Samantha Pynn is hard at work on <strong><em>Home To Win</em></strong> at the moment, and is not able to answer any more of your questions at this time. Watch Sam Pynn in action with the rest of the HGTV stars in the latest episode of <em>Home To Win</em> on <a href="https://www.hometowin.ca/video/">hometowin.ca</a>, and tune in Sundays at 10pm et for new episodes.</p></description><a10:updated>2016-05-09T16:04:00-04:00</a10:updated></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">62223</guid><link>http://www.hgtv.ca/blog/good-samaritan-offers-free-repairs-to-family-heirlooms-damaged-in-japans-recent-earthquake/</link><title>Good Samaritan Offers Free Repairs to Family Heirlooms Damaged in Japan&rsquo;s Recent Earthquake</title><description><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/goodsamaritanoffersfreerepairstofamilyhe_c763-nakamura1_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="464" title="nakamura1" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="nakamura1" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/goodsamaritanoffersfreerepairstofamilyhe_c763-nakamura1_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a>
</p><p><br></p><p>How’s this for a #feelgoodfriday: a good samaritan in Japan has offered free repairs to all family heirlooms damaged during April’s earthquake. </p><p><br></p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/goodsamaritanoffersfreerepairstofamilyhe_c763-nakamura3_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="793" title="nakamura3" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="nakamura3" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/goodsamaritanoffersfreerepairstofamilyhe_c763-nakamura3_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a>
</p><p><br></p><p>Kunio Nakamura is trained in the traditional Japanese art of pottery repair, known as Kintsugi. Through his <a href="https://twitter.com/6jigen" target="_blank">twitter account</a>, Nakamura offered his services to those wishing to repair their cherished family heirlooms. Nakamura travelled throughout the badly affected area of Kumamoto, offering repairs free of charge. When repairs weren’t possible, he offered new solutions. </p><p><br></p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/goodsamaritanoffersfreerepairstofamilyhe_c763-nakamura4_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="323" title="nakamura4" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="nakamura4" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/goodsamaritanoffersfreerepairstofamilyhe_c763-nakamura4_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a>
</p><p><br></p><p>His work is beautiful, but it’s his generosity that won our hearts.</p><p><br></p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/goodsamaritanoffersfreerepairstofamilyhe_c763-nakamura5_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="323" title="nakamura5" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="nakamura5" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/goodsamaritanoffersfreerepairstofamilyhe_c763-nakamura5_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a></p><p><br></p><p><em>Images courtesy of </em><a title="https://twitter.com/6jigen" href="https://twitter.com/6jigen"><em>twitter.com/6jigen</em></a></p></description><a10:updated>2016-05-06T14:10:00-04:00</a10:updated></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">62222</guid><link>http://www.hgtv.ca/blog/sam-pynn-saves-a-dated-kitchen-from-too-much-wood/</link><title>Sam Pynn Saves a Dated Kitchen from Too Much Wood</title><description><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsavesadatedkitchenfromtoomuchwood_aa56-sampynn-6_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="626" title="SamPynn-6" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="SamPynn-6" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsavesadatedkitchenfromtoomuchwood_aa56-sampynn-6_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a>
</p><p>Overwhelmed by wood? This homeowner definitely is. Luckily <a href="https://www.hometowin.ca/"><strong><em>Home To Win</em></strong></a> star Sam Pynn<b></b> is here to help with her trademark sage advice…</p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsavesadatedkitchenfromtoomuchwood_aa56-curetoomuchwood2_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="465" title="CureTooMuchWood2" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="CureTooMuchWood2" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsavesadatedkitchenfromtoomuchwood_aa56-curetoomuchwood2_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a><br><em>Denise’s kitchen</em>
</p><p><strong>From Denise:</strong> </p><p><i>Dear Samantha, <br>We bought our house from my in-laws and I HATE my kitchen. We are painting our cabinet doors an off-white color — the same color that's in my backsplash and my chairs and are adding paneling for more style. I want to paint the wood frame of my cupboards but I am not sure if I should and I have no idea what color I should use. <br></i><i>As you can see, we have wood galore in this house. Should I paint more than just the wood frames in the kitchen? PLEASE HELP! I just want this place to be my home with my touches. <br>Thanks, <br>Denise" </i></p><p><em><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsavesadatedkitchenfromtoomuchwood_aa56-curetoomuchwood_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="259" title="CureTooMuchWood" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="CureTooMuchWood" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsavesadatedkitchenfromtoomuchwood_aa56-curetoomuchwood_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a><br>Denise’s kitchen and backsplash colour palette
</em></p><p><strong>Sam Pynn suggests:</strong> </p><p>Hi Denise, <br>Hate is a strong word, but I totally understand why you’re feeling overwhelmed by all the wood! You’re off to a good start by adding paneling to the doors. And without a doubt you should paint the doors as well as the shell of the kitchen. </p><p>Paint the cabinet doors, shell of the cabinets, window trim and casing (sink window) all the same soft white colour. Leave only the butcher block island in wood, but do paint the island’s wood trim. </p><p>Once you’ve painted the kitchen cabinets you will feel much better about the space. Next, tackle the wainscoting, stairs and window frames. Using that same soft white is a recipe for success, but you could also get a little experimental with a biscuit colour like Benjamin Moore <a href="http://www.benjaminmoore.com/bmpsweb/portals/bmps_en_ca.portal?_nfpb=true&amp;_windowLabel=sidebarportlet_1_2&amp;sidebarportlet_1_2_actionOverride=%2Fbm%2Fcms%2FContentRenderer%2FselectSideBarArticle&amp;sidebarportlet_1_2np=public_site%2Farticles%2Fapplication_article%2Fapp_colorExplorerTool&amp;sidebarportlet_1_2isNonSecure=true&amp;_pageLabel=fh_explorecolor_ca#&amp;ce_s=CC-460&amp;ce_vm=1">Inukshuk CC-460</a> or <a href="http://www.benjaminmoore.com/bmpsweb/portals/bmps_en_ca.portal?_nfpb=true&amp;_windowLabel=sidebarportlet_1_2&amp;sidebarportlet_1_2_actionOverride=%2Fbm%2Fcms%2FContentRenderer%2FselectSideBarArticle&amp;sidebarportlet_1_2np=public_site%2Farticles%2Fapplication_article%2Fapp_colorExplorerTool&amp;sidebarportlet_1_2isNonSecure=true&amp;_pageLabel=fh_explorecolor_ca#&amp;ce_s=HC-170&amp;ce_vm=1">Stonington Gray HC-170</a>. <p>A few gallons of paint are going to make a huge difference. Once you start personalizing your house with accessories and soft touches like upholstery, cushions and window treatments, you’ll start feeling like it’s your home sweet home and no one else’s. </p><p><br>All the very best, <br>Sam</p><p><br></p><p>Please note: Samantha Pynn is hard at work on <strong><em>Home To Win</em></strong> at the moment, and is not able to answer any more of your questions at this time. Watch Sam Pynn in action with the rest of the HGTV stars in the latest episode of <em>Home To Win</em> on <a href="https://www.hometowin.ca/video/">hometowin.ca</a>, and tune in Sundays at 10pm et for new episodes.</p></description><a10:updated>2016-05-05T12:06:00-04:00</a10:updated></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">62221</guid><link>http://www.hgtv.ca/blog/sam-pynns-advice-for-a-dated-stucco-facade/</link><title>Sam Pynn&rsquo;s Advice for a Dated Stucco Facade</title><description><p><b>David from Toronto</b> wrote in to HGTV.ca looking to get advice on siding options for his family home. David and I exchanged a few emails when he pulled out the real talk and confessed that his wife is less than happy with the new black windows he convinced her on, and that if we don't help him make a cladding decision soon, he'll be facing more than the unfinished look of his home's facade…</p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsadviceforadatedstuccofacade_cbe7-samppynn-1_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="465" title="SampPynn-1" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="SampPynn-1" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsadviceforadatedstuccofacade_cbe7-samppynn-1_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a>
</p><p><b>From David:</b> “<i>Hi, we have a major dilemma. We ordered new Kolbe windows which are now installed, but still can't make a decision on house siding. The true dilemma is that I ordered the windows and promised my wife they would look all right until we made a cladding decision, but it obviously looks unfinished and she is angry with me! </i></p><p><em><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsadviceforadatedstuccofacade_cbe7-sampynn-2_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="465" title="SamPynn-2" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="SamPynn-2" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsadviceforadatedstuccofacade_cbe7-sampynn-2_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a>
</em></p><p><i>I'm thinking Cape Cod siding in grey with white trim below the soffits and painted lighter grey cedar shake on the upper half? They could be separated by a thick white trim board with white pillars (you can only see one of our pillars in the original photo). Right now our house looks like an ugly commercial building because it has very few architectural features and it's all one medium. I dislike stucco, but that's the other idea. </i></p><p><em><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsadviceforadatedstuccofacade_cbe7-sampynn-3_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="465" title="SamPynn-3" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="SamPynn-3" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsadviceforadatedstuccofacade_cbe7-sampynn-3_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a>
</em></p><p><i>Another idea was to do natural cedar shake on top with white siding below. The above example is in slightly different colours, and I have to work with my new black windows with the three-inch white trim, but you get the idea. </i></p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsadviceforadatedstuccofacade_cbe7-sampynn-4_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="465" title="SamPynn-4" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="SamPynn-4" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsadviceforadatedstuccofacade_cbe7-sampynn-4_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a></p><p><i>This is another idea, but it might be too stark.</i></p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsadviceforadatedstuccofacade_cbe7-sampynn-5_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="589" title="SamPynn-5" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="SamPynn-5" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/sampynnsadviceforadatedstuccofacade_cbe7-sampynn-5_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a></p><p><i>Lastly, a friend of mine sketched out what we were thinking, but another dilemma is the number of mediums. Can you use three different mediums on a smaller house like ours? Cedar shake, wood siding and something else for the bump out?&nbsp; <br></i><p><i>Thanks for you're help!<br>Dave”</i></p><p><br></p><p>Well it looks like Dave has done some good work on his own, but <a href="https://www.hometowin.ca/stars/samantha-pynn/">Sam Pynn</a> had great words of advice none the less…</p><p><br></p><p><b>Samantha Pynn:</b> Hi David, I love your inspiration shots! As well as the sketch. All options -- white house with vinyl siding; cedar shingles, vinyl siding, and copper roof; and, wood shingles with wood siding -- are gorgeous. I called contractor and window and siding expert, John Mazolli, of <a href="http://cerastoneltd.com/">Cerastone</a>, to discussed your options.<ul><li>You can definitely finish your home in <b>vinyl siding</b>. This will be the least expensive option. If you clad the entire house in white siding you'll be able to leave the thick window frames white, and in that case, I would suggest painting the Juliet balcony doors black to match the windows. </li></ul><ul><li>Regarding <b>shingles</b>, according to John, they're very difficult to install on top of concrete. We were unable to tell from your photo whether the facade of your house is concrete or a parge mix, but shingles are usually nailed into sheeting. It's also worth noting that cedar requires annual treating and weatherproofing. Of course it can all be done, as long as you understand the maintenance required, and that your facade will require wood framing to apply the sheeting for the shingles.</li></ul><ul><li><b>Combining different mediums</b> is perfectly fine providing you <b>paint the trim all one colour</b> to better unify the facade. Paint the double doors black (to work with your windows) and the six-inch pine molding, crown and panels all the same colour. If you are leaving the trim around your windows white (if the trim is vinyl, you're leaving it white) then paint all the trimming white. Your home would look great in a historic grey, but its current putty is also a good colour to draw on. To keep the look unified like in your inspiration shots, opt for shingles that are stained in the same tone as the colour of your siding.</li></ul><p>All the best,<br>Sam&nbsp; <p><br><p>Please note: Samantha Pynn is hard at work on <strong><em>Home To Win</em></strong> at the moment, and is not able to answer any more of your questions at this time. Watch Sam Pynn in action with the rest of the HGTV stars in the latest episode of <em>Home To Win</em> on <a href="https://www.hometowin.ca/video/">hometowin.ca</a>, and tune in Sundays at 10pm et for new episodes.</description><a10:updated>2016-04-28T14:29:00-04:00</a10:updated></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">62219</guid><link>http://www.hgtv.ca/blog/scott-mcgillivray-says-do-this-with-old-kitchen-cabinets/</link><title>Scott McGillivray Says Do This with Old Kitchen Cabinets</title><description><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/scottmcgillivraysaysdothiswitholdkitchen_ec48-scott-5_2.jpg"></a><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/scottmcgillivraysaysdothiswitholdkitchen_ec48-scottmcgillivray2.jpg"><img width="607" height="653" title="ScottMcGillivray2" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="ScottMcGillivray2" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/scottmcgillivraysaysdothiswitholdkitchen_ec48-scottmcgillivray2_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a>

</p><p>The man who needs no introduction, <a href="https://www.hometowin.ca/stars/scott-mcgillivray/">Scott McGillivray</a>, is flashing his irresistible smile in our super exciting new series <a href="https://www.hometowin.ca/"><em>Home To Win</em></a>! To bring you even more of the hosts you love, we’re revisiting some of their most popular advice in our Design Dilemma series, beginning with the time that Jen Z. wrote in to ask Scott for his advice on her old kitchen cabinets. Here’s how that went…</p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/scottmcgillivraysaysdothiswitholdkitchen_ec48-scottdesigndilemma-1_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="826" title="ScottDesignDilemma-1" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="ScottDesignDilemma-1" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/scottmcgillivraysaysdothiswitholdkitchen_ec48-scottdesigndilemma-1_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a><br><em>Jen’s kitchen</em>
</p><p><b>From Jen Z: </b><i>"We live in a small townhouse with a small kitchen. The kitchen has wooden cabinets (I think they're real?)&nbsp; I think there are a lot of people who probably feel the same way as me: How do you know when you should paint over your wooden cabinets? I hear that some people say NEVER! and others say GO FOR IT.&nbsp; Is there a rule?&nbsp; What do you suggest in our little kitchen? </i></p><p><i>Also.. how important is it to have matching appliances in a townhouse that's not on the 'high end' of the $ scale? <br>Thank you SOO much.. <br>(We would like to sell or rent our town home within the next 2 years.. if they economy gets better!) <br>Thanks,</i><p><i>Jen Z." </i><p><b><br></b><p><b><br></b><p><b>Scott suggests:</b> Jen,<p>Painting over your old cabinets is one of the most inexpensive ways to improve the look of your kitchen.&nbsp; If the cabinet doors and the boxes they are hinged on are in good condition but are looking dated then I would recommend painting them.&nbsp; <p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/scottmcgillivraysaysdothiswitholdkitchen_ec48-designdilemma-2_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="413" title="DesignDilemma-2" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="DesignDilemma-2" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/scottmcgillivraysaysdothiswitholdkitchen_ec48-designdilemma-2_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a><br><em>The Before. Photo courtesy of Scott McGillivray.</em>
<p><br><p>Here is a breakdown of the process:<p><strong>1.</strong> <b>Remove the cabinet doors</b> and the door hardware.&nbsp;&nbsp; Clean the doors with a bit of soapy water and a damp cloth.&nbsp; Let dry. <p><strong>2.</strong> <b>Sand all surfaces</b> of the door and the faces of the kitchen cabinet boxes (the narrow band of the cabinets that you can still see when the doors are on their hinges and closed.) Use 150 grit sand paper.&nbsp; Wipe off dust.<p><strong>3.</strong> <b>Choose your paint </b>colour and compatible primer.&nbsp; There are many different types of paint you can use.&nbsp; I use latex paint but some people prefer an oil based paint.&nbsp; When you buy your paint be sure to tell the person at the paint desk what you are painting to ensure you get the appropriate product.&nbsp; Bring one of the doors with you if you are not sure whether you need a melamine or wood primer. <p><b>4. Prime the doors</b> and the faces of the kitchen cabinets (do not paint the inside of the cabinets.)&nbsp; The best way to get a smooth finish is by using a pneumatic sprayer, but don't panic if you don't have access to one.&nbsp; You can paint the doors with a brush.&nbsp; When using a brush do a couple of thin coats of paint rather than one thick coat.&nbsp; This gives you a smoother finish.&nbsp; Allow 3-4 hours between coats and 48 hours of curing before re-installing the cabinet doors. <p><strong>5.</strong> <strong>Put the door hardware back on</strong> and put the doors back on the hinges.&nbsp; <p><br><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/scottmcgillivraysaysdothiswitholdkitchen_ec48-designdilemma-3_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="413" title="DesignDilemma-3" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="DesignDilemma-3" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/scottmcgillivraysaysdothiswitholdkitchen_ec48-designdilemma-3_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a><br><em>The After. Photo courtesy of Scott McGillivray.</em>
<p><br><p>Here are a few other tips for your kitchen: <ul><li>Paint the cabinets and replace the door hardware.&nbsp; The door handles on your cabinets will have two screws on the back of the door.&nbsp; Unscrew them and bring them with you to the hardware store when you are getting the paint.&nbsp; Select new door hardware that has screws at the same width as your old handles.&nbsp; </li></ul><ul><li>Replace your stove and fridge to match your microwave range hood.&nbsp; You can find fairly inexpensive white appliances online.&nbsp; </li></ul><ul><li>My final recommendation would be to<strong> </strong>lighten up the wall colour.&nbsp; Here (above) are a few before and after pictures of a small kitchen I updated recently.&nbsp; I painted the cabinets, counter tops and walls, changed the door hardware, faucet, and appliances.&nbsp; Without the appliances the cost of materials was <b>under $500</b> -- not bad eh! </li></ul><p>Good luck , <br>Scott McGillivray <br>Home To Win <p><br><p>And there you have it! If you’ve been throwing your honey-coloured oak kitchen evil glances thinking its days are numbered, don’t hesitate another second – paint it out!<p>Watch Scott in action with the rest of the HGTV stars in the latest episode of <em>Home To Win</em> on <a href="https://www.hometowin.ca/video/">hometowin.ca</a>, and tune in Sundays at 10pm et for new episodes.</description><a10:updated>2016-04-25T16:48:00-04:00</a10:updated></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">62218</guid><link>http://www.hgtv.ca/blog/toronto-outraged-over-amazing-boat-treehouse/</link><title>Toronto Outraged Over Amazing &ldquo;Boat&rdquo; Treehouse</title><description><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/torontooutragedoveramazingboattreehouse_9b83-boat%20treehouse%2001_2.jpg"><strong><img width="619" height="464" title="Boat Treehouse 01" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="Boat Treehouse 01" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/torontooutragedoveramazingboattreehouse_9b83-boat%20treehouse%2001_thumb.jpg" border="0"></strong></a><br><em>Image courtesy of </em><a href="http://news.nationalpost.com/toronto/family-gets-new-chance-for-approval-of-boat-treehouse-under-threat-of-tear-down" target="_blank"><em>Peter J. Thompson/National Post</em></a><em>&nbsp;</em><p>Toronto-based John Alpeza built his kids the backyard treehouse of their dreams but got an ugly wake-up call when he was told by the city to dismantle it. A general contractor, Alpeza invested three years in the 32m² (108 square feet) cedar structure’s elaborate construction, spending an estimated $30,000 in materials alone. His goal: encourage his children to untether from technology and play outside. Alpeza’s custom-crafted design emulates a boat, sailing the clouds to captivate his children’s imagination with on-point details including ropes to swing on, retractable windows, a dining area and a real, wooden steering wheel with compass point handles.<p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/torontooutragedoveramazingboattreehouse_9b83-boat%20treehouse%2002_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="464" title="Boat Treehouse 02" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="Boat Treehouse 02" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/torontooutragedoveramazingboattreehouse_9b83-boat%20treehouse%2002_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a><br><em>Image courtesy of </em><a href="http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/treehouse-toronto-1.3543497" target="_blank"><em>Makda Ghebreslassie/CBC News</em></a><p>Unfortunately, thoughtful parenting doesn’t assure thoughtful — not to mention legal — neighbouring. Alpeza broke sky without a permit, and the City of Toronto says he has violated zoning laws and must tear down the treehouse. As law, Toronto building staff legally assess building plans to confirm that property owners are complying with Ontario building codes, local zoning bylaws and other applicable laws. Permits give permission to build, demolish, add-on-to or renovate property, and exist to protect the interests of landowners and communities alike. As early as June 2014, a resident complained to the municipal government, citing violation of privacy; treestump-perched, the structure does overlook an adjoining backyard. An approved building permit would have guaranteed the treehouse’s security, but Alpeza did apply to three separate offices and was rejected each time.<p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/torontooutragedoveramazingboattreehouse_9b83-boat%20treehouse%2003_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="411" title="Boat Treehouse 03" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="Boat Treehouse 03" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/torontooutragedoveramazingboattreehouse_9b83-boat%20treehouse%2003_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a><br><em>Image courtesy of </em><a href="http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/treehouse-toronto-1.3543497" target="_blank"><em>Makda Ghebreslassie/CBC News</em></a>
<p>The City of Toronto has charged Alpeza for violating zoning bylaws and ignoring notices to change the plan of the design, and has ordered him to dismantle&nbsp; the treehouse. Mayor John Tory says that if changes are made, it can be saved. Despite the charges and orders, Alpeza has sworn that he will not comply. Whatever the resolution, the magic of treehouses is indisputable. Treehouse concepts date back to the Roman Era, ever-connected to play, imagination, wonder and simplicity — in today’s plugged-in world, perhaps more than ever. Alpeza had the right idea, but went more than a little off-course on the voyage. Here’s hoping everyone in this story can navigate peaceful waters successfully.</description><a10:updated>2016-04-22T11:03:00-04:00</a10:updated></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">62217</guid><link>http://www.hgtv.ca/blog/my-bad-back-and-i-tried-out-a-bed-in-a-box-and-heres-what-happened/</link><title>My Bad Back and I Tried Out a Bed-in-a-Box and Here&rsquo;s What Happened</title><description><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/bedinaboxvsbackpainhowdoesitfair_bd6b-casperlayers3_2.jpg"></a><img width="619" height="413" title="Casper6" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="Casper6" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/bedinaboxvsbackpainhowdoesitfair_bd6b-casper6_thumb.jpg" border="0"><em>Image courtesy of </em><a href="https://casper.com/" target="_blank"><em>Casper</em></a><em>&nbsp;</em></p><p>What’s a bed-in-a-box? In the last few years there’s been a mini-revolution in the business of retailing mattresses. Companies such as <a href="http://www.hgtv.ca/blog/casper-the-bed-in-a-box/">Casper</a> (one of the first) and its contemporary Leesa, followed by (strikingly) similar brands such as Endy (Canadian) and Yogabed, have made it their fight to do away with the ‘nuisance’ of shopping for a mattress in a physical store. Their solution? Retail primarily online, narrow the choices to very few – just the one, in most cases – and send your purchased mattress to your door in a compact box: ergo, bed in a box. </p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/bedinaboxvsbackpainhowdoesitfair_bd6b-casperlayers_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="402" title="CasperLayers" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="CasperLayers" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/bedinaboxvsbackpainhowdoesitfair_bd6b-casperlayers_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a><br><em>Image courtesy of </em><a href="https://casper.com/" target="_blank"><em>Casper</em></a><em>&nbsp;</em>
</p><p>“That’s crazy”, you may be thinking, “a mattress cannot be an out-of-a-box kind of solution (and how the heck do you get a mattress into a box, anyway?)”. Doesn’t one need to lie on it to feel it out? Sleep on it for days? Research the different firmness, thickness, material makeup? Aren’t our mattress needs as unique as we are – like snowflakes? </p><p>According to Casper, dear snowflakes, we are a lot less unique than we would like to imagine. Like most of its contemporaries, Casper retails just one mattress – that’s right, for all types of people and needs – because as it turns out, Casper’s extensive consumer testing revealed that an overwhelming majority of us prefer the exact same mattress profile. (Yay for simpler mattress shopping; boo for delusions of complex individualism.)</p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/bedinaboxvsbackpainhowdoesitfair_bd6b-leesalayers4_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="436" title="CasperLayers3" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="CasperLayers3" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/bedinaboxvsbackpainhowdoesitfair_bd6b-casperlayers3_5dbf541d-a907-41d1-9e6e-751475ddfee2.jpg" border="0"></a><br><em>Image courtesy of </em><a href="http://sleepopolis-mattress-reviews.com/reviews/casper-mattress-review/" target="_blank"><em>Sleepopolis.com</em></a></p><p>The breakthrough is in the makeup material: memory foam. Each of the aforementioned companies have their own, often proprietary version, made up of several layers of different density foam that look a lot like sponge cake. </p><p>But the idea is essentially the same: it seems that the way our weight is distributed on a memory foam mattress is a lot better for our back health and sleep quality than a spring mattress. A spring mattress, no matter how advanced, still cannot absorb our body weight and pressure at different points like memory foam can, which allows for all the peaks and valleys of our unique, snowflake-like shapes to find form-fitting rest however needed. And doing away with springs allows the mattress to be compressed and vacuum sealed into a package a quarter of its inflated size, perfect for launching onto physical doorsteps following the click of a virtual checkout. </p><p><img width="619" height="763" title="KylieJCasper" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="KylieJCasper" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/bedinaboxvsbackpainhowdoesitfair_bd6b-kyliejcasper_thumb.jpg" border="0"><br><em>Celebs love Casper. Here’s Kylie Jenner making a push for the brand. Image courtesy of </em><a href="https://www.instagram.com/" target="_blank"><em>Instagram</em></a><em>.</em>&nbsp; <br></p>
<p>Naturally, with every new idea there is some resistance, but despite the very kneejerk skepticism you may be feeling while reading this, the bed-in-a-box industry has taken root like a weed in the garden of traditional mattress retail because, well, customers are sleeping like the dead (one of Casper’s taglines). </p><p>Heyyyy, I thought, tearing one of my perpetually tired eyes open in attention, could this mattress also be for me? No, I don’t fancy myself unique, but I do have complications. A brief medical history: carrying my two kids has resulted in a terribly weak lower back and periodic sciatica, which recently culminated in a herniated disk at L5 requiring back surgery. Even post-surgery my lower back still hurts quite regularly and my old spring mattress wasn’t helping. </p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/bedinaboxvsbackpainhowdoesitfair_bd6b-casperonporch_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="719" title="CasperonPorch" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="CasperonPorch" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/bedinaboxvsbackpainhowdoesitfair_bd6b-casperonporch_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a><br><em>My new queen-size Casper mattress-in-a-box on my doorstep</em>. </p><p>Cut to my new queen-size Casper mattress-in-a-box on my doorstep. I decided to try it out. Why Casper? Though consumer reviews rate the different brands very similarly (the independent US mattress review site, <a href="http://sleepopolis-mattress-reviews.com/" target="_blank">Sleepopolis.com</a> gives Casper an overall score of 4 out of 5 stars, which is better than Yogabed at 3.9 but less than the Canadian Endy with 4.2 and the top-ranking Leesa mattress, with 4.8), quite frankly, I fell for their marketing (and NOT because Kylie Jenner has one). I love their whole branding shtick (they’ve a very endearing instagram account) and the whole thing feels a bit like my good friends designed me a mattress. </p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/bedinaboxvsbackpainhowdoesitfair_bd6b-elanafrankoncasper_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="464" title="ElanaFrankonCasper" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="ElanaFrankonCasper" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/bedinaboxvsbackpainhowdoesitfair_bd6b-elanafrankoncasper_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a><br><em>My mate and I on the Casper immedately after unboxing; me already loving it.</em>&nbsp;</p><p>Seeing as I have back problems I had an extra pair of hands to help me get the box up to my third-floor bedroom, but the box is indeed quite manageable should no one be available to help you. </p><p>My initial acquaintance with my Casper delivered on all the high points that the internet promised, including the satisfying goodie bag of greetings and instructions and the dramatic unfurling and inflation (watch an unboxing video of one, Michael the Sleepsage, going through the very motions, below), and I personally didn’t notice any ‘new foam mattress’ smell that many customers have noted in various reviews. </p><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/bedinaboxvsbackpainhowdoesitfair_bd6b-sharp-and-steady7_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="413" title="Sharp-and-steady7" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="Sharp-and-steady7" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/bedinaboxvsbackpainhowdoesitfair_bd6b-sharp-and-steady7_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a><br><em>Image courtesy of </em><a href="http://www.businessinsider.com/i-bought-a-bed-from-casper-2015-6" target="_blank"><em>Business Insider</em></a>
</p><p>One tragedy: see those scissors my mate is clutching to his chest like it’s the dark ages? We were so eager to watch the thing inflate to size that we completely missed the “Sharp and Steady”, a safe and handy exacto-knife included in Casper’s goodie bag that scores the mattress plastic with 21st-century ease! Watch how Michael the Sleepsage cuts through his plastic like the savvy modern man he deserves to be. If only we had a little bit more chill! <p>No matter. The point is that since the moment I touched down on my new Casper mattress – my face in the above photo says it all – life has gotten increasingly more restful and significantly less painful. It’s been three weeks since I hoofed my old mattress to the curb (btw, Casper provides you with a recycle bag for your old mattress so that you can donate it) and I have to admit, I’ve never slept better. The final verdict from this snowflake is that the second I lay down, I could feel the right absorption of pressure at all my stress points; my bubble butt and scoliosis-prone upper back and ribcage found the proper sinkage and pressure absorption, alleviating the strain on my spine and sway-prone lower back, which was definitely exasperated by the hammock effect of the old spring mattress. I wouldn’t say I am completely pain-free, but it’s the closest thing I’ve known since before my children. And hey, save for saying I’ve slept on a lot of beds (I just said it, gross), suffice it say that I’m pretty sure this may be as good as it’s going to get. <p>By the way, Casper and most of its competitors offer a 100-day-and-night (or so) trial or your money back policy, so if you’re still not sure about the bed-in-a-box, they ship to Canada (no hidden fees!) and it’s risk-free. Hey, I’d do it just to use that cutter thingamajiggy!<p><iframe width="619" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/AD9lg11Yyv8" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen=""></iframe></p></description><a10:updated>2016-04-21T17:04:00-04:00</a10:updated></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">62216</guid><link>http://www.hgtv.ca/blog/outdoor-trend-pool-floats/</link><title>Summer Will be Meaningless Without a Giant Pool Float</title><description><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/thebiggestoutdoortrendfor2016giantpoolfl_8c81-da2ca34284e3ba294cb655b8d92d1cec_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="587" title="da2ca34284e3ba294cb655b8d92d1cec" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="da2ca34284e3ba294cb655b8d92d1cec" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/thebiggestoutdoortrendfor2016giantpoolfl_8c81-da2ca34284e3ba294cb655b8d92d1cec_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a>
</p><p><br></p><p>It seems these days that whatever makes for a good Instagram, makes for a great trend. When fashion bloggers began posting shots of their #bikinibods, our eyes glazed over their teeny tiny bikinis and went straight for the oompa loompa pool floats. <a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/thebiggestoutdoortrendfor2016giantpoolfl_8c81-61ba83kngyl._sl1001__4.jpg"><img width="619" height="619" title="61BA83KNgYL._SL1001_" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="61BA83KNgYL._SL1001_" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/thebiggestoutdoortrendfor2016giantpoolfl_8c81-61ba83kngyl._sl1001__thumb_1.jpg" border="0"></a></p><p><br></p><p><a href="https://www.amazon.ca/MyToy-Inflatable-Floats-Swiming-Summer/dp/B01DJ96IDG/ref=sr_1_69?s=toys&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1461250691&amp;sr=1-69&amp;keywords=pool+float" target="_blank">Donut Pool Float</a>, $25.
</p></description><a10:updated>2016-04-21T11:30:00-04:00</a10:updated></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">62215</guid><link>http://www.hgtv.ca/blog/toronto-becomes-first-city-in-na-to-mandate-green-roofs/</link><title>Toronto Becomes First City in NA to Mandate Green Roofs</title><description><p><br><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/torontobecomesfirstcityinnatomandategree_c854-groof%2001-to_2.jpg"><strong><img width="619" height="454" title="GRoof 01-TO" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="GRoof 01-TO" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/torontobecomesfirstcityinnatomandategree_c854-groof%2001-to_thumb.jpg" border="0"></strong></a><a href="http://www.gardinergreenribbon.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Green-Roof.jpg">gardinergreenribbon.com</a><p>Toronto is well on its way to becoming Canada’s Emerald City, thanks to a bylaw that requires green roofs on new construction. Residences, commercial and institutional buildings over 2,000 square metres must have a roof that’s 20-60 percent “living.” Green/living roofs are partly or completely covered by vegetation, planted into a growing medium and sitting over a waterproof membrane. They often include structural support, irrigation and drainage systems, and can even incorporate greywater treatment ponds.<p><a name="h.9wtt9f7oe66j"></a><p><br><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/torontobecomesfirstcityinnatomandategree_c854-groof%2002-esri_2.jpg"><strong><img width="619" height="537" title="GRoof 02-ESRI" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="GRoof 02-ESRI" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/torontobecomesfirstcityinnatomandategree_c854-groof%2002-esri_thumb.jpg" border="0"></strong></a><br><a href="http://scotttorrance.ca/projects/esri-canadas-garden-in-the-sky/" target="_blank">scotttorrance.ca</a> <p>Green roofs have many benefits. They not only insulate the buildings they shelter but also improve air quality and reduce runoff, easing sewer system loads and preventing associated overflow. They cool in summer, reduce heat loss in winter, and can support birds and other wildlife. Where green roofs top public buildings, they create public green space and parkland. Living roofs can even help cool an entire city in the summer by reducing what’s known as the “urban heat island effect,” where traditional roofing and paving materials increase the overall temperature of the air. Scott Torrance Landscape Architect, Inc. designed this beautiful-yet-functional green roof atop Esri Canada in Toronto.<p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/torontobecomesfirstcityinnatomandategree_c854-groof%2003-van_2.jpg"><strong><img width="619" height="413" title="GRoof 03-VAN" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="GRoof 03-VAN" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/torontobecomesfirstcityinnatomandategree_c854-groof%2003-van_thumb.jpg" border="0"></strong></a><br><a href="http://ecozome.com/wp-content/gallery/vancouver-green-roof/globe-2010-roof-6226.jpg">ecozome.com</a><strong> </strong></p><p>Growing in popularity, green roofs can be installed on everything from your own home to a giant arena. They have a long history — from the Hanging Gardens of Babylon to sod houses in Scandinavia — but today’s green roofs use modern technology for roofs that are clean, low-maintenance and even useful (imagine growing vegetables and fruit on the unused space just above your head). Living roofs are becoming big business: the Green Roofs for Healthy Cities initiative (whose annual conference is being hosted in Toronto this year) lists over 100 corporate members, and the list is growing fast. The first city in North America to mandate green roofs, Toronto has also been a leader in installing them, with 72,000 square metres of green roof space created in 2014 alone — and permits pulled for 186,000 square metres! But it’s not just Toronto who’s in on the action. Vancouver claimed the title of the largest green roof in Canada as far back as 2010, when LMN Architects built the world’s first LEED Platinum convention center with this sedum topper.<br><br></p><p>Still need convincing of the glory of green? Studies show the increase in living roof space in Toronto will reduce sewer overflow to the tune of three extra open beach days per year. Now <em>that’s </em>progress everyone can appreciate.</description><a10:updated>2016-04-19T14:13:00-04:00</a10:updated></item><item><guid isPermaLink="false">62214</guid><link>http://www.hgtv.ca/blog/do-these-4-things-in-your-garden-at-first-sign-of-spring/</link><title>Do These 4 Things in Your Garden at First Sign of Spring</title><description><p><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/dothese4thingsinyourgardenatfirstsignofs_bad3-spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-0_4.jpg"><img width="619" height="464" title="spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-0" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-0" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/dothese4thingsinyourgardenatfirstsignofs_bad3-spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-0_thumb_1.jpg" border="0"></a>
</p>
<p>The experienced gardener tends to eye any newly sprouting green in the touch-and-go months of March and April with caution: one never knows when winter can lob a final freeze. But as soon as your spidey senses tell you that the warmth is here to stay, do these four, simple things in your garden to enjoy its bounty right out of the gate .</p><p><br></p><p><b>1. Give Your Bulbs Some Backup</b><br>Those of you who plant bulbs in the fall (crossing fingers that pesky vermin don’t devour them) want to enjoy seeing the beauties emerge, green and youthful, from under the rubble of mulch and winter debris. What can beat the sight of a healthy crocus, daffodil or tulip emerging in the spring? A simple gardening act that can help is gently hand-raking the brown matter from around the plant. Now, don’t fret if this doesn’t get completed, or if you don’t do it thoroughly: bulbs are strong, they yearn for the light and they will fight their way out of the darkness. (My crocuses don’t always get the hand-rake treatment and I still see their cheery heads peeking up from the mulch ever year.) Still, it’s worth the effort — consider it a final, small top-off investment for all that hard autumn labour.<a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/dothese4thingsinyourgardenatfirstsignofs_bad3-spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-1_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="632" title="spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-1" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-1" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/dothese4thingsinyourgardenatfirstsignofs_bad3-spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-1_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a>
<i>Hyacinths emerging (photo by Jennifer Tibbitt)<br><br></i><p><i><br></i><br><b>2. Go Slowly</b><br>Don’t rush into super-clean mode on the first nice day or weekend. Relax. Breathe. Stretch like a cat. Enjoy the sunshine. Taking care of a garden is a seasonal act of patience. Check the weather forecast regularly, keeping aware of future temperature changes and rainfall (and, yes, possible flurries). Bear in mind, though, that predicting the weather can be as unreliable as betting on a horserace. Which is all the more reason to, as suggested, <i>proceed slowly.</i><i><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/dothese4thingsinyourgardenatfirstsignofs_bad3-spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-2_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="412" title="spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-2" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-2" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/dothese4thingsinyourgardenatfirstsignofs_bad3-spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-2_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a>
<br>Tulips and daffodils, early flowering (photo by Jennifer Tibbitt)</i></p><p><em><br></em></p><p><em></em><br><b>3. Rake and Weed</b><br>Rake up those leaves, but leave some around the base of more sensitive perennials and shrubs. Weed, weed, and weed again, any time the ground can be walked on (i.e., it doesn’t feel like a squishy sponge). Not sure whether a plant is a beloved perennial or a pesky weed? Leave it alone. You’ll figure it out later in the season, as weeds are very prolific. Know thine enemy!<i><a href="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/dothese4thingsinyourgardenatfirstsignofs_bad3-spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-3_2.jpg"><img width="619" height="502" title="spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-3" style="border: 0px currentcolor; border-image: none; display: inline;" alt="spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-3" src="http://media.hgtv.ca/blogimages/dothese4thingsinyourgardenatfirstsignofs_bad3-spring-has-sprung-a-4-step-clean-up-for-any-garden-3_thumb.jpg" border="0"></a>
<br>Early red tulips, with grass background (photo by Jennifer Tibbitt)</i></p><p><em><br></em></p><p><em></em><br><b>4. Brown Bag It!</b><br>From shrubs to flowers to ornamental grasses, remove anything that is dead, diseased or damaged. Especially maple leaves with big black polka-dots — not a funky fashion statement, but a leaf blight that’s not healthy for your garden. Brown bag it all up and put it on the curb for collection. Now: Dust off your hands, place said hands on hips, and survey your outdoor domain with pride. Another job well done — and just the beginning of another wonderful, fulfilling green season.</p></description><a10:updated>2016-04-11T13:17:00-04:00</a10:updated></item></channel></rss>
